title-group.article-title: Machinability of 380 Alloy - Minor Impurity Constituent Effects

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1979

abstract.p: A small addition of magnesium (0.3%) to prime 380 die casting alloy (SAE 308) was found to improve the alloy's machinability. Magnesium hardens the matrix and by doing so ... reduces the tendency to build up on a tool edge, ... results in shorter and tighter chips, ... provides a-better workpiece surface finish, giving prime 380 desirable machining characteristics similar to those of secondary alloy. However, tool wear rates for the magnesium-modified prime alloy were significantly lower than those for secondary alloy. Other minor/impurity element alloy variations also affected machining characteristics but less dramatically than the magnesium. Some elements traditionally credited with improving machinability were found in this study to be of little benefit.

ref.mixed-citation: Walter Bonsack, "Iron - The Problematic Factor in Quality of Aluminum Alloy Die Castings." Transactions, American Foundry- men's Society, Vol. 69 (1961).

Ray P. Dunn and Warren Y. Dickert, "Mag- nesium Effect on the Strength of A380.0 and 383.0 Aluminum Die Casting Alloys." Tran- sactions, Society for Die Casting Engineers, Paper #G-T75-015, (1975).
Donald L. Colwell, "Zinc in Aluminum Casting Alloys." Transactions, American Foundrymen's Society, Vol. 60 (1952).
Mahesh C. Mangalick, "Demagging Aluminum". Die Casting Engineer, Jan. -Feb., 1974.
Machinability Data Book, 2nd Edition, Machinability Data Center, Metcut Research Associates, Inc., Cincinnati, Ohio 1972.
C. A. Queener and W. L. Mitchell, "Effect of Iron Content and Sodium Mod- ification on the Machinability of Aluminum Alloy Die Castings." Modern Castings, Feb. 1965.
